title: Simone Biles on where she keeps all those medals, her favorite athletes, her future
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: As we march towards the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, here are three fun facts about one of the United States' biggest stars, Simone Biles. USA TODAY

STUTTGART, Germany — Fresh off winning her fifth all-around title at the world championships, Simone Biles sat down with USA TODAY Sports. In a wide-ranging exclusive interview, she talked about her legacy, why she feels it’s important for female athletes to speak out, her love-hate relationship with the balance beam and what she plans to do after the Tokyo Olympics.

You said last night that sometimes you can’t believe what you’re doing. Does it ever really sink in?

Biles: I feel like we don’t have time. I feel like once it sinks in, we’re back in the States and it’s like a celebratory moment. That’s when it kind of hits you.

Can you still go out in public without being recognized?

Biles: No. It’s – I’m grateful for it, but at times, I just want to go to the store and not be recognized. So it has its ups and downs. It definitely has its perks, but it definitely has its problems, as well. Like not being able to go anywhere.

Simone Biles says she can feel like she's going in many different directions while at a competition. (Photo: Thomas Kienzle, AFP via Getty Images)

If you could go out without being recognized, where would you go?

Biles: Probably just going out with friends. If we got to an amusement park or concert, that’s the hardest.

When you decided to come back after taking a year off, did you expect that you’d top what you did in 2016?

Biles: No. I definitely thought 2016 was probably going to be the pinnacle of my career. Coming back, I was really nervous if I could top my 2016 performances.

Once we started training and putting more skills in, and we competed for the first time, I was like, 'Wow, I think I am better than 2016.' That’s what blew my mind. Just looking at the differences in the videos. Even with my form, it’s a little bit cleaner, too, on some of the things because we’ve paid attention to detail there.

You said last night you’ve finally gotten your confidence back on balance beam. What caused you to lose it and how did you get it back?

Biles: It took a while. I have this love-hate relationship with the beam. I’ve always told myself, 'If you hate beam, the beam will hate you.'

Going into 2016, I was pretty confident because at the worlds leading up to that, I had always done pretty well on beam. (Biles won the world title on balance beam in 2014 and 2015.) Then 2016 kind of shut me down. And it’s not just the performance because I knew it wasn’t the best. Even though I still got a bronze medal (at the Rio Olympics), it’s just like, what everybody else says. 'You shouldn’t even have got a bronze.'

If you watch the performance, we had two warm-ups: we had a medals ceremony (one) and we had our Team USA stuff. If you watch, I put my Team USA gear back on because I knew I wasn’t going to medal with the performance I had given. I really thought Flavia (Saraiva of Brazil) was going to have it.

Then the score came up and I barely beat Flavia. So then I had to get the medals ceremony outfit out. That’s when it kind of blew my mind, like I can have mistakes and still medal.

After that, coming back, I just didn’t want to do a performance like that. I had had repeats and I had fallen on beam, so that also shot my confidence down. I was like, 'I guess I’m just never going to do well on beam again.’ Finally this year, I took out some of the moves I was feeling a little bit uncertain with.

And I felt like every time I went to go do a front tuck or a front pike, I relived Rio. Even if they were good. I didn’t want that to happen again. So I was in a constant fear, basically.

When did that change?

Biles: Probably as soon as we took it out. Then you wonder what other skill – because it’s always something. Even if you take out a trouble skill, another skill wants to trouble you.

Thankfully it’s all good right now so I’m good.

Growing up, who was your favorite athlete?

Biles: Ooh. Alicia Sacramone.

Anyone from another sport?

Biles: I feel like Serena Williams. Just because she’s always been so dominant and she’s always spoken out and she shows her real, raw emotions. I think that’s important, that you don’t have to hide that.

You could be describing yourself.

Biles: I think I’ve learned as I’ve gotten older that it’s OK to show real, raw emotion. You don’t have to be a robot all the time, and you don’t always have to seem happy out there.

It seems as if you allow people to see who you really are. Is that a conscious choice?

I feel like it’s easier to gauge how I’m feeling. I think it also shows kids that it’s OK, if you’re enjoying the moment, to smile, to be happy. If you’re not having a good time, it’s OK, you don’t have to hide that from people. I’m not saying you should scream or punch things. You could probably do that behind the scenes. But if you’re upset you can show that you’re upset.

Where do you keep all of your medals?

Biles: My Mom keeps them in a safe. She’s the medal keeper. I actually have one – a huge shadow box with a lot of my medals that my Mom made for me. It’s at the gym, in my office. That one’s pretty cool.

Do you have a favorite?

Biles: I don’t know. As bad as it is, I always like to reflect on my (Rio) beam performance. Just because it wasn’t the best, but I still medaled so I can only be thankful for that. I feel like it also made me realize that not every performance is going to be great, but it’s not over until it’s over. I feel like going into every competition, I have to remind myself that: No matter what happens, even if it’s not the best performance, it might not be over.

I feel like every gold-medal winning performance is a highlight, but sometimes I like to think of the things that made me better as a person. It’s those times where I didn’t go out and do my best, but it still went OK in the end.

With Michael Phelps and Usain Bolt retired, you will be the face of the Tokyo Olympics. Are you prepared for that?

Biles: I’ve never really thought about that. I guess going into previous Olympics, you heard about Usain and Michael Phelps. They probably felt the weight of the world on their shoulders.

But I’m pretty good at managing that just because I try to stay focused on myself and the expectations I have for myself going in. But at times it’s overwhelming. (pause) I don’t know. Somehow, I just manage it.

I get nervous too and I have my freak-out moments. I try to just relax and calm myself. … Put some headphones on. Or you’ll see me breathing deeply so I can slow my heart rate down.

You said after team finals that you wanted to “vomit” before it started. Do you still get nervous before competitions?

Biles: Sometimes. Mainly on bars. I wish I never had to compete that again.

Simone Biles, left, has been pushed by her coach, Laurent Landi, to add new skills. (Photo: Laurence Griffiths, Getty Images)

But your uneven bars have gotten so much better with coach Laurent Landi. Did you ever foresee that?

Biles: No. No. Never in a million years.

How much, then, did your silver medal on uneven bars at last year’s worlds mean to you?

Biles: Oh my God, that was probably the highlight of my year. Of my career. It might be the only bar medal I ever get.

Is there anything left for you to accomplish?

Biles: I feel like I still have a lot to accomplish. But my main goal is to go out there and compete beam with confidence and hopefully do well in that event because I know how strong I am. Even though I got a bronze, I’m hoping for a little bit better because I know I’m capable of it.

Any more upgrades or new skills before Tokyo?

Biles: We’re kind of solidifying the things now to go into Tokyo. You don’t want to worry about upgrades going into the new year or competing them. So probably solidify them.

When Laurent suggested some of your new skills, what did you think?

Biles: I just laughed. I just thought it was funny. I’m like, 'There’s no way.' Because I thought 2016 was the peak. Anything he suggested that was outside of what I did in 2016, I was like, 'Yeah, there’s no way.’

So he suggests it, you say no way and then what?

Biles: And then I have to decide. It has to be on my terms. He can suggest it and push for it and push for it. And then it’ll be a good day and I’ll be like, 'OK, I think I can do it.’ It kind of stems from there.

What do you want your legacy to be?

Biles: I guess the dominance that I’ve had. Also, the real, raw true me. I feel like, yes, I’m an athlete, but at the end of the day, I hope they look at me as a normal person as well. With showing the emotions and the character and how I carry myself.

I think it’s important to teach our female youth that, that it’s OK to say, `Yes, I am good at this,’ and you don’t hold back. You only see the men doing it. And they’re praised for it and the women are looked down upon for it. But I feel like it’s good because once you realize you’re confident and good at it, then you’re even better at what you do.

I feel like we should teach the youth that it’s OK to say, 'Yes, I am good.’ And it’s not out of cockiness. It is what it is, at the end of the day. I’ve won five world titles and if I say, `I’m the best gymnast there is,’ (the reaction is), 'Oh, she’s cocky, look at her now.’ No, the facts are literally on the paper. I think it’s important to teach the youth that.

So do you have a GOAT T-shirt?

Biles: No, but my boyfriend does.

How important is his support and that of your family?

I think it’s important, for my whole entire family, to know that I have their support because without it, I wouldn’t be able to do what I do and be as good as I am. It just means a lot to me.

Will you really be done after Tokyo?

Biles: I think so. Probably. He (nods at Landi) wants me to go further.

Landi: It’s not, 'He wants me.’ You will not do it if it’s coming from us. You will stop when you feel it’s done.

Biles: I feel it today. Walking to breakfast I was like, 'Ooh.’

It’s going back to a five-person team (for the Paris Olympics in 2024) and you could have a specialist. But I don’t know, floor routines are hard. It’s not easy.

I’ve always just thought that I don’t want gymnastics to be my whole entire life. I just want it to be a part of my life, a piece of legacy that I put in the books. Then I have to move on and continue with the rest of my life. Whatever that may be. I don’t know yet.
description: Having qualified for all four event finals, Simone Biles likely to surpass Vitaly Scherbo of Belarus' record of 23 medals at the world championships
